column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/byron-leftwich-finds-work/|Byron Leftwich Finds Work|The man behind one of the worst Bucs offenses that Joe has seen since Stewart McClown quarterbacked team
column3: has finally found a job in football. Per NFL insider Jordan Schultz of FOX Sports
column4: Leftwich was hired by University of Colorado coach Deion Sanders today. Multiple reports including Schultz’s do not specify what Leftwich’s responsibilities will be
column5: only that he has been added to Sanders’ staff in Boulder. Given control of the Bucs offense in 2022 after Super Bowl-winning coach Bucco Bruce Arians resigned
column7: even with Tom Brady behind center. Perhaps the worst gameplan Joe has ever seen in person was when the Bucs played at Pittsburgh facing the Steelers’ vaunted run defense. Pittsburgh had so many injuries in their secondary they were pulling guys off Forbes Avenue to play. Armed with Mike Evans and Chris Godwin
column8: what did Leftwich do? He decided to ground and pound and maybe throw some dink-and-dunk passes. What made this travesty even more unnerving was that the referees working the game had a high tendency for throwing defensive pass interference flags. Yet with stud receivers going against practice squad dudes
column9: Leftwich thought it was smarter to have Rachaad White run at Cam Heyward. Brilliant! On top of that
column13: talking down to reporters who had the gall to question his genius. Whenever he was asked about using receivers in motion
column15: he scoffed and referred to that as “fantasy football.” Yet Bucs fans saw with their own eyes what motion did for the Bucs offense with largely the same personnel sans Brady the next two seasons. After Leftwich was launched in early 2023
column16: he tried to get several jobs
column18: even reaching out to Notre Dame coach Marcus Freeman for an offensive coordinator job. Instead
column19: Freeman promoted Fighting Irish tight ends coach Gerad Parker over Leftwich. Parker now coaches Troy. Leftwich’s efforts to join Mike Tomlin’s staff in Pittsburgh were unrequited. So for the first time in over two years

column6: the locker room may have been better than he expected. “Being a part of it last year

column2: though they’re symbolic of one of the great pay-per-read hoaxes of the modern era. Another guy who isn’t a fan is new Bucs inside linebacker Anthony Walker
column3: Jr. The Bucs signed the eight-year veteran inside linebacker in free agency last week and he took a shot at PFF today during his introductory Bucs news conference in Tampa. It seems there has been criticism — bad grades? — of his pass coverage
column4: but Walker says don’t believe it. “I see all the stuff on social media and everything where people be like
column7: ’ and all that. I’m here to tell you can watch the film
column8: ” Walker said. “The ball does not get completed behind me or in front of me in the middle of the field.” Joe stood and applauded
column9: and not just because the Bucs fans are desperate to heal the trauma of a season filled with watching inside linebackers K.J. Britt and J.J. Russell in pass coverage. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/anthony-walker-says-he-was-handpicked-by-lavonte-david/|Anthony Walker Says He Was Handpicked By Lavonte David|Very interesting chatter between new Bucs linebacker Anthony Walker
column2: Joe and Zoom-assembled Tampa Bay media this afternoon.  Joe kicked off the action asking Walker to explain his relationship with Lavonte David
column3: who noted Monday that he knows how hard Walker works and knows him well. Joe did not expect the response that the veteran Walker delivered. Anthony Walker
column4: Jr.: I know Lavonte pretty much most of my life. Being from Miami
column5: actually one of his close friends
column6: I played football with his little brother. So I was just always around. Once I made the NFL
column7: they kind of let me get into the group
column9: to hang with the cool kids
column11: we’ve trained together every offseason since like my third year in the NFL. You know
column13: a guy that I’ve learned from
column14: tried to model my game after and just a very good friend of mine. JoeBucsFan.com: Do you feel like he’s part of the reason that you’re here? Maybe that connection or speaking up for you? Walker:  (laughs) Yeah
column16: the respect that he has in Tampa
column20: everywhere he’s been he’s touched a lot of lives. And for him to help me get here is amazing
column21: as well. Obviously a chance to be teammates would be pretty dope. And I’ve kept telling him that. He’s said one day he was going to make it happen. We’ve been trying to get this done since I was getting drafted [in 2017] but
column23: finally able to get it done. Walker has made 83 starts in his eight seasons covering time with the Colts
column25: including eight starts in 14 games played for Miami last season. There’s very interesting depth brewing in the Bucs’ linebacker corps. Joe said interesting

column190: ""post"": ""I do hope the Bucs draft an ILB and at least one CB in the draft but trust the Bucs not to reach to fill those roster deficits.  I\u2019d be thrilled to see the Bucs use a day one or two pick on a CB but both the crop of LBs available in this draft and the relative positional value of ILBs have me hoping the Bucs wait until round four to add an ILB.  Cal\u2019s Teddye Buchanan is the best coverage LB in this draft and should be there in the fourth.  He is a former QB and proper ball hawk with 8 career INTs.  He had none last year but his film from UC Davis is absolutely electric.  Even through it is against lesser competition his elite processing and read/react talents are undeniable and he had a pair of one-hand INTs that demonstrate his WR-like ball skills.  His Cal film from 2024 is rock solid too.  It shows his ability to be an asset against the run and his natural instincts as a blitzer (33% pressure rate!)  He isn\u2019t a track star and is undersized but plays within himself and lets his exceptional awareness and processing make up it.  He is not LVD Jr.  He is the ILB that this roster needs now and he has the vision and range to close the abyss in the middle of the Bucs third down defense.  I am feeling great with LVD and Dennis starting with Deion Jones and JJ Russell behind them.  I\u2019m actually excited to have ball hawking Deion Jones as a contributor but Buchanan can contribute as a 3rd down specialist from day one.  No other ILB in this draft can hold a candle to him when it comes to coverage skills.  The best paid and PFF rated ILBs are almost all late round
column191: undersized guys.  I\u2019d be happy if Campbell and his 40 time are there at 19 but I don\u2019t think he will be and I honestly see Buchanan as the missing piece in the middle and the ILB I\u2019m pining for the Bucs to pick but not earlier than pick 84.""
